explanation:
OS_StatusToInteger: The function (or macro) called to produce the numeric value of the status. Need its signature/implementation to know if it has side effects (or contains any for-loops) that could affect loop-counter analysis when it appears in clause expressions or when invoked from a for-loop body.
snprintf: Prototype/semantics are required to confirm it has no persistent side effects other than writing to the provided buffer and to know the required types of its arguments (first argument must be char*). This matters for reasoning about objects modified in expressions used by a for-loop and whether calls in the loop body modify loop counters or other objects.
osal_status_t: The typedef of the status parameter is needed to determine its underlying type (signed/unsigned integer, enum, etc.) so that formatting with "%ld" and any conversions via OS_StatusToInteger are well-defined — relevant when considering whether expressions in for clauses use/modify such objects.
os_status_string_t: The definition (e.g., typedef char[N] vs typedef char *) is required because sizeof(*status_string) behavior depends on it. If it is an array type, sizeof yields the buffer length; if it is a pointer type, sizeof yields pointer size — this affects whether the buffer argument to snprintf is correct and whether the code may modify objects that a for-loop clause relies on.
size_t: The type produced by sizeof and used by snprintf second argument; known semantics of sizeof/size_t are needed when reasoning about whether sizeof expressions in for clauses have side effects or depend on objects modified in the loop body.
